Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Enriching Security Curricula and Enhancing Awareness of Security in Computer Science and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is building our nation's capacity to develop a workforce well trained in computer security. Faculty from the University of Houston, University of Houston-Downtown and Texas Southern University, are developing interactive courseware and conducting workshops on the latest machine learning, data mining, natural language processing and statistics techniques as applied to computer security. Courseware on security-critical domains such as wireless sensor networks, and on key societal privacy and security concerns is also being developed. Workshops are being organized to cross-fertilize security curricula with related fields and topics and to develop a broad-based consensus on courseware contents. In addition to interactive courseware for security courses, materials are being developed to infuse security topics and increase awareness of information assurance in the broader computer science curriculum and, beyond computer science, in other STEM disciplines. A hypertextbook integrating the courseware is being implemented.

Through faculty workshops, a community of information assurance education and research scholars is being created. This community builds bridges between information assurance professionals and professionals in related fields. The workshops are training diverse groups of faculty from different types of institutions.

Courseware and other results are available in the National Science Digital Library as well as at a project-specific web site which also links to exemplary courseware developed elsewhere. Courseware and workshops are being rigorously evaluated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have reported our TSU's activities and coycomes on this project to PI (Dr. Rakesh Verma) in the Project leading Institute  -- University of Houston. The leading PI Dr. Verma has included all of our Inputs and submitted the final project outcomes report to NSF. Please look at the final submission for this project outcomes report from the project leading Institute. More project outcomes have also been included in the project website http://capex.cs.uh.edu/.

In addition to above final submission of the project outcomes report to NSF from leading Institute, the TSU faculty members also actively led the activcities in the investigation, review and dissemination of the security education, organized various workshops, and developed curricular materials related to security education, and particularly led the completion of the following six educational modules: (1) Module on Mobile Devices Security (MMDS); (2) Module on Mobile Applications Security (MMAS); (3) Module on Concept of Privacy in Data Mining (MCPDM); (4) Module on Privacy Preserving Data Mining Algorithms (MPPDMA); (5) Module on Implementation Issues in Security Systems (MIISS); (6) Module on Security and Protocoals in WSN (MSPWSN). TSU faculty investigators also took the leadership in organizing the security workshop as orgnaization Chairmen and produced a numebr of peer-reviewed publications such as in IEEE Transaction on Wireless Coomuincations and IEEE Transactsions on Vehicular Technology et al.
